CO2: None of the other properties change in the 100 year time scale
Volcano: Both volcanoes and mountains are slowly changing forcers.  In this scenario, volcanoes decrease and mountains increase
Mountains: In 200 years, neither shows a change in level.
Insolation: Insolation and C release by weathering will not change throughout the scenario.

Temperature: Temperature responds quickly to a change in CO2 level.
CO2: The drop in volcanoes lowers one of the CO2 sources (without changing the sinks).  CO2 level decreases as a result.
Volcano: Volcanoes decreased, lowering one of the CO2 sources.
Ice: Temp. decrease triggers polar ice accumulation, raising ice level.
Sea: A decrease in temperature drops sea level (thermal contraction).  Also, accumulation of polar ice removes water from the ocean, lowering sea level.
Weathering C Burial: A decrease in temperature decreases rainfall, lowering weathering.
CO3 Desposition: Lowering weathering lowers the amount of C and Ca that washes to sea, lowering carbonate deposition rate.
Sediment: Lowering weathering rate deceases the amount of sediment delivered to the sea, decreasing carbon burial.

Temperature: Temperature responds quickly to a change in CO2 level.
CO2: The drop in volcanoes lowers one of the CO2 sources (without changing the sinks).  Higher mountains increase one of the sinks (carbonate deposition). CO2 level decreases as a result.
Ice: Temp. decrease triggers polar ice accumulation, raising ice level.
Sea: A decrease in temperature drops sea level (thermal contraction).  Also, accumulation of polar ice removes water from the ocean, lowering sea level.
Weathering C Burial: A decrease in temperature decreases rainfall, lowering weathering.
CO3 Desposition: Lowering weathering lowers the amount of C and Ca that washes to sea, lowering carbonate deposition rate.
Sediment: Lowering weathering rate deceases the amount of sediment delivered to the sea, decreasing carbon burial.  This is not a huge change, though, from the 100,000 year time scale

Temperature: Lower atmospheric CO2 results in lower temperature
CO2: The drop in volcanoes decreases one of the CO2 sources; the rise of mountains increased at least 1 of CO2's sinks (could impact both).  CO2 drops as a result.
Ice: Lower temperatures trigger more polar ice accumulation.
Sea: Polar ice accumulation lowers sea level.  Also, lower temperature and less volcanoes (less mid-ocean ridge activity) also lower sea level.
Weathering C Burial: A decrease in temperature decreases rainfall, lowering weathering.
CO3 Desposition: Lowering weathering lowers the amount of C and Ca that washes to sea, lowering carbonate deposition rate.
Sediment: Lower weathering rate decreases the amount of sediment delivered to the sea.  However, build up of glaciers add a rich source of sediments, increasing the sediment rate at this point.
